item.title: The First Night
item.description: An ultra-Orthodox Jewish filmmaker asks members of her community about the silent anxieties surrounding intimacy on their wedding nights.

item.title: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish Couples on the Anxiety Around Their Wedding Night
item.description: An ultra-Orthodox Jewish filmmaker asks members of her community about the silent anxieties surrounding intimacy on their wedding nights.

item.title: The Way to Pay for Free Buses Is to End Free Parking
item.description: Free buses would be transformative not only for riders, but for the ecosystem of the city as a whole.

item.title: MAGA and the Country Aesthetic
item.description: Why country and cowboys have a hold on our culture and our political imagination.

item.title: The Problem With Abolishing Property Taxes
item.description: Suburban professionals want amenities, not austerity.

item.title: Is There Life for MAGA After Trump?
item.description: A field guide to the movement and its future.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern Designed New York City Like a 1930s Movie
item.description: He was, in the very best way, the Ralph Lauren of architects.

item.title: The Medical Case for Self-Driving Cars
item.description: Compared to human drivers, Waymo cars were involved in 91 percent fewer crashes that resulted in serious injuries.

item.title: Japan’s New Clarity on Taiwan Is a Wake-Up Call
item.description: The Japanese leader’s candor over Taiwan brought the shared regional stakes out into the open, and the U.S. must stand behind its ally.

item.title: Olivia Nuzzi Isn’t Telling All
item.description: Olivia Nuzzi doesn’t seem to recognize that her collaboration with Robert Kennedy was a grave professional betrayal.

item.title: Ukraine Is Not a War of Attrition
item.description: Victory will belong not to the side with more resources, but to the side with the stronger, more adaptive and unyielding will to win.

item.title: How to Prepare Your Kids for the A.I. Revolution
item.description: I help to build A.I. systems, and even I know there are real reasons to be concerned about how A.I. affects our children.

item.title: Cory Booker Wants You to Have Hope
item.description: “If America hasn’t broken your heart, you don’t love her enough,” Cory Booker tells David Leonhardt in this episode of “The Opinions.”

item.title: Farewell to the Beloved Friend in My Window
item.description: Winter won’t hold forever, and when it comes, a spider will disappear from the corner where she has made her home.

item.title: Don’t Be Fooled by the Silence in America’s Backyard
item.description: Latin Americans have proved surprisingly acquiescent to U.S. aggression — but that won’t last forever.

item.title: The Aftermath of the D.C. Shooting
item.description: Readers discuss the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington. Also: Being Latino in the U.S.; wonderful mentors.

item.title: How I Began to Love Reading Again
item.description: I needed to stop thinking that I knew more than the author and give in to whatever ride they had spent years planning.

item.title: Why Hepatitis B Vaccine Changes Would be Devastating
item.description: Changes to the vaccine recommendation could be disastrous.

item.title: It’s OK That Our Long, Mostly Good Marriage Ended
item.description: Four years ago, my husband and I made an increasingly common choice: We hugged, apologized for our shortcomings and freed each other.

item.title: The Quest for Perfection Is Stunting Our Society
item.description: It is not only classical musicians who are being harmed by the search for perfection. It is harming many aspects of our lives and sectors of our society.

item.title: I’m Building an Algorithm That Doesn’t Rot Your Brain
item.description: Jack Conte, the chief executive of Patreon, a platform for creators to monetize their art and content, outlines his vision for an internet that puts people, not ad revenues, first.

item.title: This Is the Story of How the Democrats Blew It on Gaza
item.description: It may be tempting to memory hole what happened in Gaza. That would only compound the mistake of ignoring, or rationalizing, an intolerable reality.

item.title: Goodbye, Price Tags. Hello, Dynamic Pricing.
item.description: Shopping has always been a game. And now it’s being rigged against you.

item.title: Donate This Holiday Season: Eyes Ears Nose & Paws Needs Your Help
item.description: A North Carolina organization delivers salvation on four legs.

item.title: Americans Won’t Have Faith in the Rule of Law Until the Law Works for Them
item.description: Mandatory arbitration, underfunded enforcement and corporate malfeasance have eroded Americans’ trust in institutions. It’s time for government to fight back.

item.title: The Medical Case That Still Haunts Me
item.description: A doctor grapples with a patient’s incomprehensible medical decision.

item.title: ‘Hamnet’ Reimagines Shakespeare for the TikTok Generation
item.description: Our love of his plays have led to a centuries-long fascination with the writer. So why does each new fictional iteration get his life so wrong?

item.title: What I Love When I Love America
item.description: My love of country this Thanksgiving season is not based on what this or that politician does, but on what America has always been.

item.title: A Kitchen Cure for Depression
item.description: As long as I get myself to pay attention, there is too much going on in the kitchen world for me to spin off into anxious abstraction.

item.title: A Pardoned Turkey, an Unpardonable Man
item.description: Many affluent Americans no longer believe in civic institutions or community groups.

item.title: America Has Sidelined Education. You Can Help.
item.description: The New York Times Communities Fund has partnered with charities that invest in education at critical junctures across people’s life spans.

item.title: Trump Misunderstands the Education Department’s History
item.description: The U.S. first had a federal education department in 1867 — not 1979. Its history is critical in understanding the federal role in schools.

item.title: Donate This Holiday Season: New Life Centers Needs Your Help
item.description: When ICE arrived in Chicago, this group had an answer.

item.title: The Uneasy Mix of God and Country
item.description: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about Christian nationalism. Also: A hope for a different kind of president; a view of Meta as not a monopoly.

item.title: Forget Therapy. I’m Turning to Magic.
item.description: Instead of going to therapy for $100 a week, I began to invest in an astrological session every few months.

item.title: How We Became ‘Half in Love With Easeful Death’
item.description: Apocalyptic predictions may actually serve as comforting fantasies, at which point our future freakouts become an excuse for inaction.

item.title: The Salmon That Surprised Everyone
item.description: Although nature is sometimes very fragile, decades of conservation rhetoric have perhaps overstated that fragility.

item.title: How Diaries Can Help Beat Back Artificial Intelligence
item.description: In a world taken over by the digital, hard-copy, handwritten diaries are a way to fight back.

item.title: Donate This Holiday Season: NICU Parents Need Your Help
item.description: The organization provides critical support to families of sick newborns, making a lonely and devastating experience a little less so.

item.title: Donate This Holiday Season: Undocumented Immigrants Need Your Help
item.description: These organizations are squeezed between an expanding need for their services and an administration trying to starve them of resources.

item.title: Goodbye, Price Tags. Hello Dynamic Pricing.
item.description: Shopping has always been a game. And now it’s being rigged against you.

item.title: ‘We Are Going to Have to Fight Three Wars’
item.description: How much will Trump ask Zelensky to pay for peace in Ukraine?

item.title: Don’t Celebrate Franco. Bury Him.
item.description: Fifty years after the death of the Spanish dictator, his legacy lives on.

item.title: A ‘Floor’ on Abortion Is Still a Limit
item.description: Readers respond to an editorial about access to abortion. Also: A citizenship test for our leaders.

item.title: Goodbye, Price Tags. Hello, Dynamic Pricing.
item.description: Shopping has always been a game. And now it’s being rigged against you.

item.title: Why We Need Fairy Tales in the Digital Age
item.description: The internet is a dangerous place. Folklore can teach us how to move through it.

item.title: Mamdani, His Mother and a Movie of Prescient Grace
item.description: The mayor-elect ran a hopeful campaign amid ugly insinuations about 9/11. When I recall where I was on that day, I have a very different association.

item.title: The Uniquely American Heartbreak of Yet Another Tragedy
item.description: The National Guard members shot in Washington are the latest victims of a political violence permeating our society.

item.title: Trump’s Greedy Thanksgiving
item.description: This year, it’s not about giving back; it’s about getting yours.

item.title: Extreme Measures for the Fentanyl Crisis
item.description: Readers respond to a guest essay about America’s fentanyl problem. Also: A dark echo at Penn.
